She sent envoys to Ranjit\nSingh and implored him to use his influence to get her husband released and in\nreturn for his help promised him the Koh-i-noor diamond.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ranjit Singh marched against the Afghans and\ngot Shah Shuja released.&nbsp; After securing\nthe Koh-i-noor diamond, Ranjit Singh had the prized jewel fitted in his turban.\nLater he had it sewn into an armlet, which he wore on all the important state\noccasions, where it remained for twenty years.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Before Ranjit Singh\ndied in 1839, his priests tried to get him to donate the diamond to the Temple\nof Jaggannath.&nbsp; Apparently he agreed, but\nby this time he was unable to speak due to a stroke , and the keeper of the\nroyal treasure refused to release the stone, on the grounds that he has not\nreceived such orders.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kohinoor signed away to\nqueen Victoria in 1849 by 11 year old boy King Duleep Singh while in\nexile.&nbsp; As a reward he could play with\nthe royal kids in London.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The terms of the\ntreaty, at the end of the Second Anglo-Sikh War specified that: \"The gem\ncalled Koh-I-noor, which was taken from Shah Shuja-ul-Mulk by Maharajah Ranjit\nSingh shall be surrendered by the Maharajah of Lahore to the Queen of England.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">John Lawrence, the\ncolonial administrator, put it in his waistcoat pocket and forgot about it.\nWhen asked for the prize, Lawrence had no idea where it was. Racing home, he\nasked his servant- who said, yes, he had found a small box, containing a piece\nof glass in his master\u2019s waistcoat!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After gaining the\nfamous diamond, the Governor General, Lord Dalhousie immediately sent the\nKoh-i-noor to England after taking every care to ensure its safe passage over\nthe land and the sea-routes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On 6 April 1850 the\nKoh-i-noor left the shores of India on board of the HMS Medea. &nbsp;So shrouded in\nmystery was its departure that even the Captain of the Medea did not know the\nprecious cargo his ship carried.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was delivered to Sir\nJ. W. Logg, Deputy Chairman of the British East India Company, who presented the\ndiamond to Her Majesty, Queen Victoria, in the presence of Sir John Hobhouse,\nat Buckingham Palace on July 3 1850.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n</div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; line-height: 150%; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-ekiRCnEFR_8/URnaFp-hWSI/AAAAAAAAe0M/7AZQEVulnE4/s1600/hms+medea.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"223\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-ekiRCnEFR_8/URnaFp-hWSI/AAAAAAAAe0M/7AZQEVulnE4/s320/hms+medea.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Prince Albert hired stupid \"experts\" at Coster Diamonds in Amsterdam to cut the diamond\ninto a brilliant, reducing it by up to 43% of its original size, which made it\nlose its natural divine moonlight blue glow.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Probably they tried to\nget rid of the curse attached to the diamond.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Little do the British\nknow that their great empire went into decline and the mental acquity of their\npeople eroded ( MAD COW ) </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">as a result of\nthe curse of the Kohinoor.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Such great stones\ncannot be mined but are found on riverbeds in their natural state. &nbsp;6100 years ago a slave stole it from Lord\nKrishna when he was sleeping.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Edward VIII , abdicated\nthe throne to his brother King George VI ( Ruler of India ) within 362 days .\nGeorge was a misfit, terribly shy with a stutter. He would cry and was prone to\nmelancholy. His English subjects never knew that he could NOT speak without a\nendless stammer.&nbsp; This suited Rothschild\n, as he could conduct 2nd World War to carve out the state of Israel, as he\nwanted , with Winston Churchill whose Jewish mother Jenny Jerome, was of\nRothschild blood.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">King George\u2019s wife&nbsp; Elizabeth ( present queen\u2019s Elizabeth II\u2019s\nmother ) was very shrewd and managed all affairs with an iron will. She got the\ngreat Kohinoor diamond stolen from India for her own crown , and was most of\nthe time sozzled on leg bucklin' ZAZA ( this is 30% gin and 70% dubonnet\n--neat-- with a slice of lime ).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-JrVDW9abGPE/URnYh2py8fI/AAAAAAAAezw/Q7Dp7uW_MUU/s1600/images+(3).jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"282\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-JrVDW9abGPE/URnYh2py8fI/AAAAAAAAezw/Q7Dp7uW_MUU/s320/images+(3).jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharaja Gulab Singh\ncame from a distinguished Dogra-Rajput Royal lineage, unlike Ranjit Singh who\nwas a commoner. &nbsp;Gulab Singh was a &nbsp;Ikshvaku Surya Vansi &nbsp;&nbsp;blue\nblooded Rajput, one of the most ancient and respected lineages of India . Lord\nRama is the 'kuldevta' (family deity) of the Dogras. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Gulab Singh Dogra and\nwas born on October 21, 1792 to Kishore Singh, whose grandfather was the\nbrother of the illustrious king of Jammu namely, Raja Ranjit Dev.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In his childhood Gulab Singh was sent by his\nfather for martial training to his grandfather Zorawar Singh, who was one of\nthe most ferocious &nbsp;tough warriors of\nthis planet.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Gulab Singh learnt\nmartial arts at a very young age, and in course matured into a great soldier. In\na single combat Ranjit Singh with one eye, stood no chance against Gulab Singh\non foot or on horse. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharaja Ranjit\nSingh had dispatched Bhai Hukma Singh (Chimni) to annex Jammu in the year 1808.\n&nbsp;A young and reckless 16 year old Gulab\nSingh ( without informing his grandfather ) quietly joined in the battle and\ndue to the astonishing resistance put forward by him and his small group\nagainst the superior Sikh forces, &nbsp;the\nSikh forces were forced to withdraw to Saidgarh. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eventually,Maharaja Ranjit Singh sent\nre-inforcements and was able to annex Jammu to his Sikh empire. &nbsp;Bhai Hukma Singh was greatly impressed by the outstanding\nleadership and exceptional fighting abilities of this young prince Gulab Singh\nand told about this to Maharaja Ranjit Singh. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In in the year 1809 Maharaja Ranjit\nSingh invited Gulab Singh to Daska a village situated a few miles from Sialkot\nand personally requested him to join his army.&nbsp;\nUltimately due to the services rendered and loyalty displayed by Gulab\nSingh, Maharaja Ranjit Singh made Gulab Singh, the Raja of Jammu. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Any other vested version by British and Sikh\nhistorians is wrong, and was written more to make the Sikhs hate the Rajpiuts,\nand break their alliance. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ranjit Singh\nwas NOT the type to be arm twisted against his better judgement.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The widow of Kharak\nSingh, Mai Chand Kaur was crowned as the reagent thereafter on 2nd December,\n1840 and she retained the able , wise and loyal Dhian Singh as her prime\nminister.&nbsp; Unfortunately soon Mai Chand\nKaur and the son of Maharaja Ranjit Singh (from Mehtab Kaur), namely Sher Singh\ncame into conflict due to a Rothschild conspiracy and Mai Chand Kaur abdicated\nand Sher Singh was declared as the Maharaja.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mai Chand Kaur was poisoned and\nthen stoned to death by her maid servants on 11 June, 1842. Though historians\nsay that , Mai Chand Kaur was put to death by the orders of Maharaja Sher\nSingh, it is well known that this was again a British conspiracy\u2014to divide the\nSikhs into various warring camps.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Soon enough Maharaja\nSher Singh along with his son Prince Pratap Singh and Dhian Singh were also\nkilled by the Sikh Chiefs, the Sandhanwalias on 15th September 1843 after being\nbribed by the British.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British official\nJoseph Davey Cunningham, residing in Ludhiana during that period circulated the\npropaganda that Maharaja Sher Singh was killed by Dhian Singh and then the Sandhanwalias\nkilled Raja Dhian Singh.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The gullible Sikhs got confused and angry and nobody\ntrusted a Rajput or even a fellow Sikh. Poison was indeed injected in the\nsimple minds of the Sikhs. How quickly the Sikhs forgot the loyal services of\nDhian Singh.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Retribution would be\nquick. The son of Dhian Singh ( and nephew of Maharaja Gulab Singh) aided by\nhis uncle Suchet Singh took revenge on the Sandhanwalia chiefs. &nbsp;The Sandhanwalia culprits Ajit Singh, Lehna\nSingh and about 600 of their gang were mercilessly put to the sword by the\ntough Rajputs.&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Interestingly when the\nwidow of Dhian Singh heard that her son had avenged the murder (in the true\nRajput tradition) of his father she mentioned to her son ,\"I will tell\nyour father that you acted as a brave and a dutiful son\", and she committed\nSati. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Dhian Singh\u2019s son Hira\nSingh, was handsome, wise and brave and was a favourite of Maharaja Ranjit\nSingh.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British who were\nlooking for an opportunity to seize the territories of the late Maharaja Ranjit\nSingh were obviously delighted. Lord Ellenborough the Governor General of India\nduring that period wrote to her Majesty Queen Victoria on October 20, 1843,\n\"...it is impossible not to preceive that the ultimate tendency of the\nlate events at Lahore is without, any effort on our part, to bring the plains\nfirst, and at somewhat later period the hills, under our protection or\ncontrol.\"<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cqWsY40jl3k/URtAqwZFuSI/AAAAAAAAe4o/5GIAmNXIEzM/s1600/imagesnhtredd.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"317\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cqWsY40jl3k/URtAqwZFuSI/AAAAAAAAe4o/5GIAmNXIEzM/s400/imagesnhtredd.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After this the youngest\nwife Maharani Jindan Kaur crowned her son Duleep Singh as the Maharaja on\nSeptember 18, 1843.&nbsp; Hira Singh , the son\nof the slain Shian Singh who was made the prime minister.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Hira Singh was killed\non December 21, 1844, along with his relatives, another of Rothchild\u2019s\nconspiracies \u2013 for Hira Singh was as wise , loyal and level headed as his\nfather Dhian Singh. &nbsp;However, brave Hira\nSingh died after giving a fierce fight.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharani Jindan Kaur\nnow made her own sweet brother Jawaher Singh the prime minister . She surprisingly goaded\non by her own ambitious brother, &nbsp;\"the son\nof the dog keeper\", &nbsp;made all efforts were\nmade to beleaguer Raja Gulab Singh. . Eventually a conflict developed between\nthe Lahore Sikh Durbar and Raja Gulab Singh.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Things got from bad to\nworse and shove became push. Eventually a great battle took place on the plain\nof the Satwari and the Jammu forces commanded by Diwan Hari Chand routed the\nSikhs.&nbsp; The divide was now complete and\nthe British were very happy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Remote controlled intrigue\n&nbsp;in the Lahore Durbar continued and Jawahar\nSingh \u201cthe ambitious to be king\u201d &nbsp;commoner\nbrother of Maharani Jindan was killed by the orders of the Panch (military\ncouncil) for his role in the killing of Prince Peshora Singh one of the sons of\nthe late Maharaja Ranjit Singh.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jawahar\nSingh was beheaded, right in front of Maharani Jindan Kaur and her young son\nMaharajah Duleep Singh, on September 21, 1845. &nbsp;The death of her own brother right in front of\nher eyes, was something too much for the Maharani to bear, who gave vent to her\nanguish with loud cries of lamentation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Britain&nbsp; now declared war on the Sikhs , giving the\nlame excuse that the Sikhs did NOT allow the passage of the British troops\nthrough their territory during the first Afghan War of the 1839-1842. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Sikh army commanded by Tej Singh (\nappointed by Jindan Kaur ) had crossed the Sutlej on December 11, 1845, &nbsp;ostensibly to occupy a former Sikh possession,\nthe village of Moran, named after one of Maharajah Ranjeet Singh's favorite\nMuslim courtesans, on the east side of the river.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tej Singh and Lal Singh DELIBERATELY broke the Amritsar Treaty signed by Maharaja Ranjit Singh in 1809.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British considered this\nas a hostile move , breaking the Amristar treaty of 1809, and hence declared\nwar. &nbsp;Tej Singh was bribed by the British to do this. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-c97cmVIA6HI/URqFls9jiJI/AAAAAAAAe2I/ZQ9bZsiMHrI/s1600/vgjkkkib.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"251\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-c97cmVIA6HI/URqFls9jiJI/AAAAAAAAe2I/ZQ9bZsiMHrI/s320/vgjkkkib.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lal Singh the clandestine\nlover of the Queen Jindan kaur and the army chief Tej were in direct\ncommunication with the British, giving away camp and battle positions and\ntactic . <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The cannons would not\nfire as our Romanian Jew Dr. John Martin Honigberger made sure they would NOT\nfire. &nbsp;This was exactly the same modus\noperandi with Tipu Sultan in 1799, when Rothschild\u2019s &nbsp;French arm fiddled around with the gunpowder.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9J72UiWm5Kk/URqFxwBaCzI/AAAAAAAAe2Y/JOSbgwnB628/s1600/imageskkllo.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"234\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9J72UiWm5Kk/URqFxwBaCzI/AAAAAAAAe2Y/JOSbgwnB628/s400/imageskkllo.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tej Singh led his own dang\narmy to deliberate defeat, during the First Angle Sikh war on December 13th\n1845 . &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\">60,000 ferocious Sikhs who fought their hearts out, could NOT handle 8,000 British , lowering the proud Sikh army morale for ever. &nbsp;</span></b><span style=\"font-size: small;\"><o:p></o:p></span></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red; font-size: large;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5V_Pug9cLMU/URqFsFomakI/AAAAAAAAe2Q/JaE5Ys_XSIo/s1600/imagesghjkl;%5B.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"251\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-5V_Pug9cLMU/URqFsFomakI/AAAAAAAAe2Q/JaE5Ys_XSIo/s400/imagesghjkl;%5B.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British troops\nshowed no mercy and the result was a massacre of thousands of Sikh soldiers. &nbsp;The Rothschild planted Jewish French and\nItalian mercenary commanders were involved in this too .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<span style=\"color: blue; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; line-height: 150%;\">Below Tej Singh.</span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/--gQ0jcn1px8/URoqqZsIrpI/AAAAAAAAe0w/mVrPYPSoy3Y/s1600/300px-Raja_Tej_Singh_(1799-1862).jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/--gQ0jcn1px8/URoqqZsIrpI/AAAAAAAAe0w/mVrPYPSoy3Y/s320/300px-Raja_Tej_Singh_(1799-1862).jpg\" width=\"214\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tej Singh whilst\nfleeing the battlefield destroyed bridges and even planted guns on his side of\nthe river to shot any escaping Sikhs!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;\u2014 Well, well ! how do you like Rothschild\u2019s\nconspiracies now? &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">All this came to light\nonly in 1857, during the First war of Independence , when the whole of India\nfought mutinied against the British except the Sikhs.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">YES! &nbsp;Tej Singh , the traitor &nbsp;raised Sikh cavalry regiments to aid the\nBritish. His scattered Jagirs were consolidated and he was rewarded with the new\ntitle Raja of Batala.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Gulab Singh had tried in vain to convince Maharani Jindan to avoid a conflict with the British. Raja Gulab Singh during this conflict took no\nsides but still had sympathy for the Sikhs and sent them food and animals. &nbsp;He then left for a pilgrimage to Vaishno Devi\nand Purmandel.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharani Jindan fervently\nsummoned Raja Gulab Singh . &nbsp;Eventually\nRaja Gulab Singh, his son Ranbir Singh, nephew Jawahar Singh along with four\nthousand horsemen and about five thousand Rajputs of his clan left for Lahore.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On arriving in Lahore Raja Gulab Singh was informed by Maharani Jindan that she\nhad lost control of the affairs of the State. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the Durbar held on\nJanuary 31, 1846, Maharani Jindan was cursed by the Panchas . The Punchas\nmentioned that Maharani Jindan was pushing the Sikh kingdom towards destruction\nby moving the army across the Sutlej River, against the British. In addition\nthe Panchas also made it clear to Maharani Jindan that they would kill her if\nshe did not make Raja Gulab Singh the prime minister.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The battles between the\nSikhs and the British were not decisive intially but with time the British\nstarted to make gains. Eventually on February 10, 1846, Sir Hugh Gough attacked\nthe Sikhs at Sobraon with heavy artillery and the Sikhs suffered bad reverses. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On accepting the prime ministership, Raja\nGulab Singh made it clear he would only continue in this position only if the\ncourt officials gave it in written that they would not interfere with his peace\nefforts with the British. &nbsp;By now\nMaharani Jindan who was inexperienced in matters of the state became panicky.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sir Hugh Gough was\nsupported by Lord Hardinge, the governor-general, who volunteered to serve\nunder him. The Sikhs were overwhelmed and Gulab Singh sued for peace at Lahore.\n&nbsp;(The services of Sir Hugh Gough were\nrewarded by Rothschild and he was elevated to the peerage of the United Kingdom\nas Baron of Maharajpore and the Sutlej in April 1846.)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Below : Baron Gough</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-M5dOVZ2HfII/URoqVCeOk7I/AAAAAAAAe0o/qxnh0KcIWS4/s1600/220px-Hugh_Gough,_1st_Viscount_Gough,_St._Helen's.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-M5dOVZ2HfII/URoqVCeOk7I/AAAAAAAAe0o/qxnh0KcIWS4/s400/220px-Hugh_Gough,_1st_Viscount_Gough,_St._Helen's.jpg\" width=\"237\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While Raja Gulab Singh\ncontinued to be the prime minister he and Lal Singh, the lover of Maharani\nJindan Kaur ( and the biological father of Duleep Singh ) did not get along. &nbsp;Lal Singh &nbsp;made several attempts were made on the life of\nRaja Gulab Singh. &nbsp;Finally Lal Singh\nforced &nbsp;Maharani Jindan Kaur to dismiss\nGulab Singh and he became Prime Minister on 26 February, 1847. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British were firm\nin their demand of two crore rupees from the Lahore Durbar as a fine and also\nwanted the Doab territory as reparation.&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eventually the boy king\nMaharaja Dalip Singh was bought to Lahore for forcing a treaty.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some of the conditions\nof the peace treaty that was signed in Lahore between the Lahore Darbar and the\nBritish East India Company, on March 9, 1846, soon after the war ended, are as\nfollows :-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">1) The Jullundur Doab\nbetween the Beas River and the Sutlej River to be surrendered to the British.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">2) The Lahore Darbar to\npay an indemnity of 15 million (1.5 crore) rupees.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">3) Maharajah DULEEP\nSINGH to continue as ruler of Punjab, with his mother Maharani Jindan Kaur\nremaining as regent.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">4) The Sikh army was\ngreatly reduced in size from its original 80,000 to around 20,000 thousand\ntroops, that set the stage for the second Anglo-Sikh war.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">5) The British troops\nwere to be withdrawn from Lahore by the end of the year 1846.</span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lal Singh now the Prime\nMinister could not come up with the money which he was supposed to pay to the\nBritish. &nbsp;&nbsp;A conniving Lal Singh hence decided to kill\ntwo birds with one stone and one of the birds being Raja Gulab Singh. &nbsp;Lal Singh subsequently made an offer to the\nBritish that he, &nbsp;Lal Singh was willing\nto offer all the hill territory to them between the rivers Sindh and Beas\nincluding Kashmir and Hazara in place of rupees one crore. &nbsp;As this included the territory of Jammu this\nwas indeed a clever way of marginalizing Gulab Singh. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Gulab Singh learnt\nabout this he felt &nbsp;felt double-crossed. &nbsp;He then met the Governor General to access the\nsituation. &nbsp;The clever Governor General realized\nthat it was a good thing to have the Rajputs as allies and he knew the loyalty\nGulab Singh commanded with Sikhs, Rajputs, Muslims and Hindus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eventually after\ndiscussions with the British, Raja Gulab Singh sent Diwan Jwala Sahai his\nconfidant to the British with the request that the territory of Jammu be handed\nover to his dependents for their support, while Raja Gulab Singh would himself\nlead a retired life in the holy city of Varanasi.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">However, it seems that\nLord Hardinge had his own plans and informed Diwan Jwala Sahai that he would be\nwilling to hand over the territories lying between the source of Beas including\nthe areas of Kashmir and Hazara to Raja Gulab Singh. &nbsp;&nbsp;In\nexchange for these territories Raja Gulab Singh was to pay rupees one crore to\nthe British. &nbsp;Since Raja Gulab Singh\ncould not come up with this kind of money, hence, he decided to trade some\nterritory on the the right side of the Beas River for less money. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On receiving this\nproposal from Raja Gulab Singh, Lord Hardinge wrote the following to a secret\ncommittee, \"that the trans Beas portion of Kulu and Mandi with the fertile\ndistrict and strong position of Nurpur and the celebrated fort of Kangra and\nthe key to the Himalayas in native estimation with its districts and its\ndependencies should be in our possession\". Eventually it was accepted that\nRaja Gulab Singh would pay 75 lakhs to the British for the smaller territory. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On finding out that\nthey had been outwitted and the tables turned on them, Lal Singh and Maharani\nJindan dispatched the loyal but wily Kashmiri Brahmin Diwan Dina Nath to Henry\nLawrence and Frederic Currie. The aim being to request the British to cancel\ntheir deal with Raja Gulab Singh and that they (Lahore Durbar) was willing to\npay all the money in order to retain their territory. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the British were\nkeen to get rid of the volatile Sikh threat to their Empire, hence, they found\nthat the best strategy was to stick with Raja Gulab Singh. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Eventually Raja Gulab\nSingh was invited by the Governor General at a camp on March 15, 1846.\nFollowing this Raja Gulab Singh was bestowed with the title of a Maharaja and\nthe Treaty of Amritsar was signed between the British and Maharaja Gulab Singh\non March 16, 1846. &nbsp;As a result of this\ntreaty Maharaja Gulab Singh found himself in possession of the State of Jammu\nand Kashmir.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">By Article 1 of the Amritsar\nTreaty, Gulab Singh acquired \"all the hilly or mountainous country with\nits dependencies situated to the eastward of the River Indus and the westward\nof the River Ravi including Chamba and excluding Lahul, being part of the\nterritories ceded to the British Government by the Lahore State according to\nthe provisions of Article IV of the Treaty of Lahore, dated 9th March,\n1846.\" <o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Under Article 3, Gulab\nSingh was to pay 75 lakhs (7.5 million) of Nanak Shahi rupees (the ruling\ncurrency of Punjab) to the British Government, along with other annual\ntributes.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Treaty of Amritsar\nmarked the beginning of Dogra rule in Kashmir, which was to end in 1948 after\nan attack by the Pakistani army which led to Indo-Pakistani War of 1947.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Lord Hardinge gave the\nfollowing reason for the transfer of Jammu and Kashmir to Maharaja Gulab Singh,\n\" It was necessary last March to weaken the Sikhs by depriving them of\nKashmir\".<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Getting back a bit in\ntime \u2014</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharajah Ranjeet Singh\nwas succeeded by his eldest son Kharak Singh from his second wife, Raj Kaur,\ninstead of his eldest surviving son Sher Singh by his most senior wife, Mehtab\nKaur, daughter of Rani Sada Kaur. The succession caused a lot of bitterness\namong Ranjit Singh's heirs. &nbsp;Opium addict\n,spiritual and soft, Kharak Singh was not fit and prepared to rule his father's\nvast empire, and was unable to control the various factions within his kingdom.\n<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Therefore, Kharak\nSingh's eldest son Nau Nihal Singh, who was just 18 years old took control of\nthe kingdom himself from his father, on October 8, 1839. &nbsp;Kharak Singh died of poisoning on November 5,\n1840, and Nau Nihal Singh was to formally take over as king after his father's\ndeath. &nbsp;However, unfortunately when Nau\nNihal Singh was returning from his father's funeral, he was fatally injured by\ndebris from a collapsing archway that smashed his head. &nbsp;It is not known whether the building collapse\nwas accidental or deliberate. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Nau Nihal\nSingh, was succeeded by Sher Singh, the eldest surviving son of Ranjeet Singh\nby his most senior wife Rani Mehtab Kaur, who was believed by many to be the\nactual claimant to the throne of the Punjab, after Ranjeet Singh's death. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sher Singh's succession did not come\nautomatically. He won the throne only after a protracted siege of the Lahore\nfort, that was held by the Royal family. He was installed as king, in January\n1841, but was himself killed just two years after taking office, in September\n1843, together with Prime Minister Dhian Singh in a plot hatched by the\nSandhawalias, cousins of Sher Singh. Raja Dian Singh's son . &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Raja Hira Singh,\nwith the support of the army, wiped out the Sandhawalia faction, and captured\nthe fort of Lahore. Then on September 16, 1943, the army proclaimed Ranjeet\nSingh's youngest son, Duleep Singh who was just five years old, as king, with\nhis mother Jindan Kaur as regent and Dhian Singh\u2019s son Hira Singh was appointed\nas Wazir.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Treaty of Bhyroval\nwas intended to tighten the noose on the Punjab, and to supercede the clause of\nwithdrawing&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">the British troops from Lahore\nas agreed by the first treaty of Amritsar in 1809 with Maharaja Ranjit Singh..</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to this new\ntreaty signed on December 16, 1846, Maharani Jindan Kaur was removed as regent\nto her son Maharajah Duleep Singh, and replaced by a British Resident in Lahore\nSir Henry Lawrence, supported by a Regency Council. This was ironically headed by the\ntraitor Tej Singh, ( the double agent of Rothschild ) the former commander of\nthe Sikh army, who treacherously facilitated the British victory in the first\nAnglo-Sikh war. The appointment of Tej Singh caused a lot of anger and\nresentment among the Sikh population.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<span style=\"color: blue;\">Below: Sir Henry Lawrence</span><br />\n<span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-jMjZMeO7ur4/URqDEZymvuI/AAAAAAAAe1s/YVjU9k-kOQE/s1600/sir+henry+lawrence.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-jMjZMeO7ur4/URqDEZymvuI/AAAAAAAAe1s/YVjU9k-kOQE/s320/sir+henry+lawrence.jpg\" width=\"306\" /></a></div>\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Meanwhile&nbsp; the British were waiting for the slightest\npretext to separate the mother and the son. The pretext was cooked up &nbsp;when the boy king refused to confer the title as\nRaja of Sialkot in Aug 1847, at instigation of his mother Jindan Kaur. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Pg-2Z8SwSVo/URqHcy_slHI/AAAAAAAAe24/17xXTn17D78/s1600/6Calendar-dec.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"256\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-Pg-2Z8SwSVo/URqHcy_slHI/AAAAAAAAe24/17xXTn17D78/s320/6Calendar-dec.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British tried to\nimplicate the Maharani &nbsp;in a conspiracy\nknown as the Premilla Plot, in which Sir Henry Lawrence and Tej Singh were to\nbe murdered at a fete at the Shalimar Gardens. &nbsp;&nbsp;A sham\ninquiry held into both incidents &nbsp;and on\nthe orders of Henry Lawrence, the mother and son were separated, and Maharani\nJindan Kaur was sent to the Summan Tower of Lahore Fort, from where she was\ntransferred to the fort at Sheikhurpura, for incarceration in September 1847. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Whither honour?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Her annual allowance\nwas drastically reduced from Rs 150,000 to a mere Rs. 48,000. &nbsp;She was then moved to the Fort of Chunar in\nUttar Pradesh, from where she escaped to Nepal disguised as a maid-servant, on\nApril 19, 1849. &nbsp;he fled to the Himalayas\ndisguised as a beggar woman, and moved to Kathmandu, in Nepal, where she was\ngiven political asylum by the Prime Minister Jung Bahadur, mainly as a mark of\nrespect to the memory of the late Maharajah Ranjeet Singh.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The British\nauthorities confiscated all her gold and jewelry, said to be worth around a\nfortune &nbsp;which also included the fabulous\nemerald and seed-pearl necklace, that had been left in the government treasury\nat Benares, and rescinded her pension. &nbsp;Maharani\nJindan Kaur's exile in Kathmandu, Nepal, lasted for over ten years, until 1860.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The second Anglo-Sikh\nwar began as a localized rebellion on April 18, 1848, in the Muslim dominated\nMultan in southern Punjab. It was &nbsp;sparked by the killing of two British officers\nwho accompanied the new governor, General Khan Singh Man to Multan. &nbsp;This started a rebellion and pent up feelings\nof the Sikhs spilled over.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lyn1PTM-CAg/URqFO1zCfyI/AAAAAAAAe14/ZC505c61jGg/s1600/imagesk,lkgtf.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"320\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-lyn1PTM-CAg/URqFO1zCfyI/AAAAAAAAe14/ZC505c61jGg/s400/imagesk,lkgtf.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sikh soldiers who\nescorted the new governor and the British officers from Lahore, defected and\njoined Mulraj's rebel army. &nbsp;As news of\nthe rebellion spread, large numbers of Sikh soldiers deserted the regiments\nloyal to the Lahore Durbar, and joined the rebels under the leadership of\nMulraj. &nbsp;None of the Sikh soldiers were properly paid.</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-mLB1aiwOcD8/URqFVt6_jSI/AAAAAAAAe2A/iISD0hAnZO4/s1600/imagesjjkuh.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"253\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-mLB1aiwOcD8/URqFVt6_jSI/AAAAAAAAe2A/iISD0hAnZO4/s400/imagesjjkuh.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The news of the rebellion reached Lahore on April 21, 1848, and Currie\nsought for assistance from Governor-General Dalhousie and Hugh Gough, the\ncommander of the Bengal army, to suppress the rebellion at Multan. However,\nGough and Dalhousie decided not to send any assistance until the end of the hot\nweather and the monsoon seasons, which would be in November. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The \"Battle of\nGujrat\" has gone down in the history of British imperialism in India, as\nthe biggest battle in terms of men and weaponry, and came to be known as the\n\"Battle of Guns.\" &nbsp;Here also\nthe bribed foreign mercenary commanders of the Sikhs deliberately provided poor\nleadership allowing the British to slaughter the Sikh army.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_n966RiTakE/URqAMG9spEI/AAAAAAAAe1k/G8U9tZRa6xU/s1600/battle-of-gujrat-2-nd-anglo-sikh-war.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"278\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-_n966RiTakE/URqAMG9spEI/AAAAAAAAe1k/G8U9tZRa6xU/s400/battle-of-gujrat-2-nd-anglo-sikh-war.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Sikhs fled in confusion,\npursued by the cavalry and horse artillery. The battle was over within a few\nhours. The Sikhs lost more than 5000 men, and the British casualties were less\nthan 100.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Ranjit Singh\u2019s European\nmercenary generals were:<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Jean-Fran\u00e7ois Allard--\nFrench<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Jean-Baptiste Ventura \u2013\nItalian <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Paolo Di Avitabile \u2013\nItalian <o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Claude August Court \u2013\nFrench<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Josiah Harlan \u2013 American\n, later governor of Gujrat<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><i>Alexander Gardner \u2013\nAmerican (Scots \u2013 Irish)<o:p></o:p></i></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mercenaries are a\nunique breed who have have NIL loyalty to a person.&nbsp; Their loyalty is to money and \u201cwhat is in it\nfor me\u201d..&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On March 14, 1849, the\nwhole Sikh Army of around 22,000 men, surrendered. &nbsp;\"Today our Maharaja Ranjeet Singh is\ntruly dead,\" &nbsp;sighed the brave Sikh soldiers,\nas they kissed the swords with tears flowing down their cheeks, and laid them\ndown on the ever-enlarging heap of steel. &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-EpN8B7xCkbs/URqAHBuuELI/AAAAAAAAe1c/OUc3zJ5moPA/s1600/maharajah-ranjith-singh-the-lion-of-punjab.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-EpN8B7xCkbs/URqAHBuuELI/AAAAAAAAe1c/OUc3zJ5moPA/s400/maharajah-ranjith-singh-the-lion-of-punjab.jpg\" width=\"276\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On March 29, 1849, Lord\nDalhousie proclaimed the annexation of the Punjab. &nbsp;His foreign secretary, Sir Henry Meirs Elliot,\narrived at Lahore to obtain the signatures of the minor king Maharajah Duleep\nSingh and members of the Regency Council. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharajah Duleep Singh\nheld his last court at Lahore, on March 29, 1849. &nbsp;A grand Darbar was held in the Lahore Fort,\nwith the British troops lined up on his right, and the Sardars of the Regency Council\non the left, the boy king Duleep Singh affixed his royal signatures in great pomp\nto the document which deprived him of his crown and kingdom.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was a poignant sight, even for the British.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">After the proclamation\nof the Punjab, as part of the British Empire in India, on March 29, 1849, the Sikh\nflag was taken down and the British flag was hoisted on the citadel of Lahore. &nbsp;Lord Dalhousie assigned Dr. John Login, the\nimportant task of taking the Koh-i-Noor and other famous jewels into the safe\ncustody of British officials in Lahore, from the \"Toshakana\" (jewel\nhouse), whose custodian was the treasurer of the Punjab Government. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\n\"Toshakana\" had the single largest and valuable collection of jewels\nand jewelry in the world. The court jewels were well preserved either wrapped\nin soft cloth or secure inside their velvet-lined cases. The most famous and\nvaluable jewels, such as the \"Koh-i-Noor\" and the \"Timur\nRuby\" were taken into the custody of Dr. John Login, to be sent\nsubsequently to London as \"gifts\" for Queen Victoria. The British\nofficials were tripping over each other to see the fabled &nbsp;\"Koh-i-Noor Diamond\" .<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The relevant section of\nthe treaty read tersely as follows :- \"The gem called the Koh-i-Noor which\nwas taken from Sha Shuja-ul-Mulk, by Maharajah Ranjeet Singh, shall be\nsurrendered by the Maharajah of Lahore to the Queen of England.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The items were listed\nin seven printed catalogues, and the sales took place over five successive\ndays, from 28th November 1850 to 2nd December 1850. &nbsp;Some of the jewels were boxed in Bombay, by\nFrazer and Hawes, and sent to London, where they were sold by Garrards.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharajah Duleep Singh was\neleven years old at the time he was deposed by the British on March 29, 1849.&nbsp; He was entrusted to the care of Dr. John\nLogin, &nbsp;by Governor-General Dalhousie. &nbsp;Dr. Login took Duleep Singh from Lahore to\nFatehgarh, in Uttar Pradesh, on December 21, 1849, \u201cin order to keep the boy\naway from the influences of the Punjab\u201d , his former kingdom. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He was provided\nlavishly furnished houses in Fategarh and also in Lucknow, where he spent his\nremaining days in India, before being exiled to Britain in 1854. &nbsp;&nbsp;Thus he\nspent almost five years in India after he was deposed, before being exiled to\nBritain. &nbsp;&nbsp;During this period he came under the tutelage\nof both Dr. Login and Bhajan Lal, a Christian convert, both of whom exposed the\npoor boy to a lot of Christian text and literature. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;;
