font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Governor-General\nDalhousie had instructed Dr. Login, that the boy should be completely\nanglicized and \u201ccivilized\u201d before he was sent to Britain to see Queen Victoria.\n&nbsp;It was in keeping with these\ninstructions that Duleep Singh was raised in complete isolation from his own\ncountrymen and tight restrictions were placed on who he was allowed to meet. &nbsp;No Indians except trusted servants, were\nallowed to meet him in private. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh's\nclosest childhood friends were both English, one the child of an Anglican\nmissionary. &nbsp;The child's brain-washing\nwas&nbsp; complete before he attained his 15th\nbirthday, and he was converted to Christianity, at Fatehgarh, with the\nblessings of Governor-General Dalhousie.&nbsp;\nHe was then exiled to Britain in 1854.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">His early years in the\nUnited Kingdom, until his settlement in Scotland, where he earned the nickname\n\"Black Prince of Perthshire\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh arrived in\nEngland in 1854, and was initially lodged at Claridge's Hotel in London, before\nthe Rothschild arranged a house for him in Wimbledon and later at Roehampton,\nwhich became his home for 3 years. Queen Victoria adopted him as a godson, and showered\na lot of fake affection on the young turbaned Maharajah, so did the Prince\nconsort, Prince Albert.&nbsp; The young prince\nbecame well known for his lavish life style, hunting trips and a love for\nwearing the funny Scottish highland costume.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In spite of the luxurious\nlife that he was leading in the United Kingdom, Duleep Singh was well aware\nthat he was a virtual prisoner in the hands of his British hosts. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">His separation from his beloved mother traumatized\nhim , and he</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">was desperate to see his\nmother, and be re-united with her. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">In\n1860, Duleep Singh secretly sent one of his native attendants to Kathmandu to get\nsome </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">information about his mother. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">A report was sent to England through the\nBritish Resident in Nepal that, Maharani Jindan Kaur had changed over the years\nand was now blind and physically weak, taking little interest in her\nsurroundings, and what was going on around her.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ranjeet Singh\nimmediately made a fervent appeal to Queen Victoria for permission to see his\nmother, and if circumstances permitted to bring her back to England to reside\nwith him. The Queen granted permission after consulting Rothschild . It was\ndetermined that the Maharani no longer posed a serious threat to British\ninterests in India.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Nepalese Government which had been on a confrontational\ncourse with the Maharani, imposing humiliating restrictions on her under\nBritish pressure, were happy to get rid of her and facilitated the meeting by\nappealing on her behalf. The Maharani herself was tired of her exile and\nisolation, and the indignity she had been made to suffer during the 10 years of\nher exile in Nepal, and was longing to re-unite with her only son.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The meeting\nwas arranged in Calcutta at the Spence's Hotel. Duleep Singh set sail to\nCalcutta in late 1860, and the Maharani was taken overland from Kathmandu\nto&nbsp; Spence's Hotel in Calcutta. The meeting\ntook place in January 1861, and the mother and son were re-united for the first\ntime in 13\u00bdyears (1848 to 1861). It was an emotional moment for both the mother\nand son.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0R5utquZLxU/URqHUwGeFZI/AAAAAAAAe2w/nwtpZ-pINIc/s1600/jindan+kaur.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-0R5utquZLxU/URqHUwGeFZI/AAAAAAAAe2w/nwtpZ-pINIc/s1600/jindan+kaur.jpg\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh set sail\nto England with his mother from Calcutta.&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh found her\nmother almost blind and suffering from poor health, although she was relatively\nyoung, and only 43 years old. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Her\npremature aging was caused by trauma, her long years of isolation and incarceration.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh returned\nto London with his sick mother, and took a house in Bayswater. He stayed there\nwith his mother Maharani Jindan Kaur for the next two years. Lady Login noted\nchanges in Duleep Singh's behavior ever since he returned to London with his\nmother. For the first time she heard him talking about his vast private\nproperty in Punjab, information that only his mother could have given him. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Maharani during her long conversations\nwith her son seem to have reawakened her son's true faith and royal heritage,\ntelling him stories of all that had been lost to the British. &nbsp;The Logins were worried about the Maharani's\ninfluence on her son, and tried to persuade Duleep Singh to find his mother a\nseparate house. But, Duleep Singh would not listen to the Logins, for fear of\nhurting her mother's sentiments..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharani Jindan Kaur\npassed away in Kensington , England on 1<sup>st</sup> Auh 1863, at the age of\n46 and her body is moved to the Dissenters Chapel, until it could be taken to\nIndia for cremation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The passing away of his\nbeloved mother was a terrible blow to Duleep Singh, and he felt orphaned in his\ncountry of adoption, with no relatives or friends from his own country.\nAccording to Sikh traditions the Maharani's body had to be cremated and her\nashes scattered in a river. But cremation was not allowed under English law at\nthat time. Thus with the intervention of John Login the Maharani's body was\nmoved to the Dissenters Chapel at Kensal Green Cemetery, until such time that\nit could be taken to India for the last rites.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At a simple funeral ceremony\nheld at Kensal Green, Duleep Singh addressed the small gathering of mourners,\nthat included a number of Indian dignitaries and the Maharani's retinue that\nshe had brought with her, in his native language Punjabi. Her body was kept at\nKensal Green for almost an year, before permission was granted to take the body\nto India for cremation, which had been her dying wish.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharani Jindan Kaur's\nbody was cremated by the banks of the Godavari river, and the ashes scattered\nin the river, and part of the ashes entombed in a Samadhi built by the river.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Duleep Singh\naccompanied his mother's body to India in 1864, but he was not given permission\nto take the body to Punjab. A small memorial containing part of her ashes was\nerected on the left bank of the Godavari river.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><span style=\"color: blue;\">Below\" Samadhi of Maharaja Ranjit Singh at Lahore</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-nIX3G5FkCGY/URp_0nJ07eI/AAAAAAAAe1U/mgW0sb6OoMQ/s1600/samadhi-of-ranjeet-singh-in-lahore.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"241\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-nIX3G5FkCGY/URp_0nJ07eI/AAAAAAAAe1U/mgW0sb6OoMQ/s320/samadhi-of-ranjeet-singh-in-lahore.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In 1924, Maharani\nJindan Kaur's granddaughter Princess Bamba Sutherland, carried her ashes from\nBombay to Lahore and deposited it at the \"Samadhi\" of Ranjeet Singh,\nfulfilling the death wish of her grandmother.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XsLhGMGr6QY/URp_fc7ZCgI/AAAAAAAAe1M/-_iDAMBN9jc/s1600/maharani-jindan-kaur-emerald-and-seed-pearl-necklace.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"239\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XsLhGMGr6QY/URp_fc7ZCgI/AAAAAAAAe1M/-_iDAMBN9jc/s320/maharani-jindan-kaur-emerald-and-seed-pearl-necklace.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The fabulous Emerald\nand Seed Pearl Necklace of Maharani Jindan Kaur was sold at the Bonham's auction\nof October 8, 2009, for a sum of only \u00a355,200. &nbsp;It was well known that the king\nsized dazzling green emeralds were replaced by ones of lesser fire by Rothschild.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ws9MtJS0Z2w/URqHI-zIMxI/AAAAAAAAe2o/dqwTzqc-AhI/s1600/47477413_q.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"200\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-Ws9MtJS0Z2w/URqHI-zIMxI/AAAAAAAAe2o/dqwTzqc-AhI/s200/47477413_q.jpg\" width=\"200\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The velvet-lining on\nthe lid of the case carried the following inscription in English :- \"From\nthe Collection of the Court of Lahore formed by HH The Maharajah Rungeet Singh and\nlastly worn by Her Highness The Late Maharanee Jeddan Kower.\"(sic!)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jindan Kaur\nre-converted Duleep Singh to Sikhism, and then petitioned the British Crown to\nhave his kingdom returned. &nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">He never\nreceived any justice or the respect he deserved.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp; </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">He died in 1893, in Paris, France.</span><br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Duleep returned\nfrom burying his mother in India he was introduced to a honey pot Bamba Muller\nby Rothschild\u2019s agents\u2014half German Jew and half Ethiopian. It is rumored that\nthis girl was of Rothschild blood on her father\u2019s side. &nbsp;She was an illegitimate girl who was working\nat a missionary school in Cairo.&nbsp; He\nbrought her back to England as his wife and they lived a life of luxury and\nwere known to Queen Victoria.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bamba Sutherland\nwas their first child, and was named after her mother, her maternal grandmother\nand her paternal grandmother respectively. The name \"Bamba\" means\npink in Arabic. &nbsp;In 1924 permission was\nfinally given &nbsp;for Jindan Kaur\u2019s &nbsp;ashes to be buried in Lahore. &nbsp;It was Princess Bamba Sutherland who\nsupervised their transfer from Bombay where they had been placed when her\nfather Duleep Singh visited India. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Bamba\nSutherland was widowed in Lahore when her husband died in 1939. She was the\nlast survivor of a royal family who should have owned the Punjab. &nbsp;When she died on 10 March 1957 at the age of 89,\nher funeral was arranged by United Kingdom Deputy High Commissioner in Lahore. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The rites were\nwitnessed by a few select Pakistani dignitaries. The Pakistani authorities did\nnot allow any of her distant relatives to attend, Sikh or Hindu, nor were any\nSikhs in Pakistan allowed to attend her rites. Thus no Sikh was present at\nPrincess Bamba's funeral, the last of Dalip Singh's line. &nbsp;So much for Muslim and Christian mentality. &nbsp;She was NOT a terrorist.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like I said before\nDuleep Singh\u2019s &nbsp;first wife was Bamba\nMuller, by whom he had six children, three boys and three girls. After the\ndeath of his first wife in 1887, &nbsp;Duleep\nSingh, took his second wife Ada Douglas Wetherill, by whom he had two children,\nboth girls.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the last surviving\nmember of the dynasty, &nbsp;Bamba Sutherland left\na large quantity of important historical items to her secretary, Pir Karim\nBakhsh Supra of Lahore. The collection consists of eighteen paintings, fourteen\nwatercolours, 22 paintings on ivory and a number of photos and other articles.\nThe collection was sold to the Pakistan government and it is kept in Lahore\nFort. It is known as the Princess Bamba Collection.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A translation of the\nPersian epitaph on her gravestone has been translated as:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\ndifference between royalty and servility vanishes<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nmoment the writing of destiny is encountered<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If\none opens the grave of a dead<o:p></o:p></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">None\nwould be able to discern rich from poor<o:p></o:p></span></i><br />\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bqfuAtLL6Rk/URsmbNjYqII/AAAAAAAAe34/IBfEdJm4cRU/s1600/220px-Gora_kabristan_lahore_headstone_sutherland_bamba_1957.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"201\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-bqfuAtLL6Rk/URsmbNjYqII/AAAAAAAAe34/IBfEdJm4cRU/s320/220px-Gora_kabristan_lahore_headstone_sutherland_bamba_1957.jpg\" width=\"320\" /></a></div>\n<i><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></i></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Pakistanis could NOT\navoid sarcasm even on the tombstone -- such is the lack of culture!. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In\nhis memoirs Karl Wilhelm referred to Princess Bamba Sutherland as \u2013 \u201c the true\nheiress of Maharaja Ranjit Singh' . &nbsp;For\nshe was most conscious of the actual desperate situation of the whole family. She\nconsidered the Punjab and Kashmir as the lost possession of her family and was\nabsolutely furious when the border between Pakistan and India was drawn right\nacross the Punjab.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Princess Bamba's\neyes, Pakistan or India did not exist, there was just the Punjab and its\ncapital Lahore. &nbsp;She met distant\nrelatives throughout her travels in India, trying to have one last glimpse of\nthe glory that she was denied. &nbsp;In her\nmind she was the legitimate Queen of the glorious Sikh empire of Punjab.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like I said before none\nof Duleep Singh\u2019s children has any issue. &nbsp;All the children , boy and girl , were made\nsterile in a covert manner \u2014 such is the sordid tale of &nbsp;British\nintrigue and treachery. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">British justice!! \u2013 say\nagain?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\">There was an incident\nof a young tiger cub being caught by shikaris.&nbsp;\nWhen Maharaja Ranjit Singh came to know that the mother tiger was running\naround in search of her cub, and moaning all night, he ordered it to be\nreleased to join the tigeress.</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-02NGrz1udPU/URsmQ0mKCII/AAAAAAAAe3w/eJdMt8zvVqQ/s1600/FFG.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"350\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-02NGrz1udPU/URsmQ0mKCII/AAAAAAAAe3w/eJdMt8zvVqQ/s400/FFG.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Maharaja Ranjit Singh\ndied at Lahore on June 27, 1839. &nbsp;&nbsp;At the time of his death, he ruled over an\narea of one lakh, forty five thousand square miles. &nbsp;But what is significant is that for the first\ntime in a thousand years, he reversed the traditional direction of attacks on\nIndia and also laid down fresh frontiers for her. &nbsp;Attacking armies started to push northwards\ninstead of pressing south as heretofore. The northern boundary of Pakistan\ntoday is, to an inch, the same as the boundary of the Sikh kingdom<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here is a British\naccount of Maharaja Ranjit Singh\u2019s last journey--<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Ranjit Singh died,\nhis body was bathed with fragrant waters, embalmed and then dressed in rich\nclothes and decorated with ornaments as when he was alive. &nbsp;The sacred Bhagwad Gita was placed on the\nMaharaja\u2019s chest and, Dhian Singh, having touched the body of his royal master\nand the book, swore loyalty to the new Maharaja Kharak Singh.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Maharaja\u2019s body was\nplaced on a decorated pier (Hawan) shaped like a ship. &nbsp;As the funeral procession advanced, large\namount of coins &nbsp;were thrown amongst the\ncrowd as alms.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For the first time in their lives, the Ranis of the Great\nMaharaja came out unveiled from the harem and followed the corpse bare-footed. &nbsp;They were dressed in pure, white silk and wore\nno ornaments. &nbsp;They had distributed all\ntheir jewels and valuables among the poor before leaving the Zenana for the\nfinal Sati. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In front of each Rani, at a\ndistance of two or three paces, a man with his face turned towards her walked\nbackwards. &nbsp;He held a looking glass\nbefore the Rani in front of whom he walked that she might see that her facial features\nwere composed &nbsp;and unaltered-- that her\nresolution to sacrifice her life had no effect on her outer appearance.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The funeral pyre was\nconstructed of sandalwood in the form of a square, six feet high and upon it\nwere strewn inflammable substances such as cottonseeds etc. &nbsp;The bier, having been brought close to it, its\nvaluable ornaments and coverings were given away to the people. The Brahmins\nand Gurus then recited passages from their holy books and offered prayers. &nbsp;This took about half an hour.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ascent to the\nfuneral pyre was by a ladder. &nbsp;The\nministers and Sardars first ascended and helped in gently removing the royal\nbody from the bier and placing it on the pyre. The four Ranis, with\ndeath-despising intrepidity, &nbsp;then\nascended the fatal ladders one by one, according to their rank and solemnly occupied\na place at the head of their royal husband, holding the head with their hands.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nRajput princess of Kangra Guddan had his head on her lap . The 7 beautiful slave\ngirls, with equal courage and contempt for death, then ascended the ladder and\nplaced themselves at the foot of their lord.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The sathis having thus\nseated themselves were covered with red mats, on which oil had been profusely\npoured. &nbsp;Raja Dhian Singh at this moment\napproached the Ranis and begged them to offer prayers for the prosperity of the\nnew Maharaja, but not a word was uttered by the Ranis, who with eyes closed and\nhand stretched towards the head of the Maharaja, which they were holding,\nmaintained a solemn silence in expectation of the final moment.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A strong, thick mat of\nreeds was then brought and saturated with oil with which all were covered. The\nMinister, Raja Dhian Singh and the Sardars then came down. Then Dhian Singh\nsuddenly lost his composure and overwhelmed with grief , insisting on being\nburnt with the Ranis. &nbsp;Thrice, he even\nattempted to force his way forward and it was with difficulty, that he was physically\nprevented from sharing the fate of the sathis. For the new king Karakh Singh was a dull witted person.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Oil, atta and ghee were then profusely thrown\non the pile. This being done, Prince Kharak Singh lit the pyre at each corner.\nIn almost the twinkling of an eye, the unfortunate creatures who had been\ncovered with the mats had ceased to exist and in a short time the whole mass\nwas reduced to ashes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">On the third day, the\nashes of the dead were picked out by the members of the family and put in\nseparate urns and, placed in separate tents made of Kashmiri shawls, the poles\nof which were wrought with gold and silver. &nbsp;Preparations were then made to send the ashes\nto the Ganga.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The remains of the Maharaja and those of the Ranis, were placed\nin separate, richly caparisoned palanquins and brought out, in state, from the\nFort. &nbsp;They were accompanied by costly\npresents such as valuable shawls, richly decorated elephants and horses, gold\nand silver utensils, rich cloth etc., which were to be distributed as alms\namong the Brahmins at Hardwar. On the procession leaving the Fort, a royal\nsalute was fired.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The procession\ntraversed the principal bazaars and streets; housetops, windows and balconies\nwere all filled with spectators. The door of the palanquin that contained the\nashes of the Maharaja was open; those of the other four containing the remains\nof the Ranis were closed.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mourning was observed\nfor thirteen days, the mourning costume being white. On the thirteenth day, the\nlast funeral obsequies were gone through and thousands of rupees lavished on\nBrahmins and fakirs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Before the fatal and 4<sup>th</sup>\nstroke on June 22, 1839, the Maharaja was managing the affairs of the state as\nefficiently as before. &nbsp;After the third\nstroke attack in 1838 he was unable to speak while his mind was still\nactive.&nbsp; He would give orders through the\nlanguage of signs while the faithful minister Fakir Azizuddin would reduce them\nto writing and ensured their implementation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">According to a British\nhistorian, \u201cRanjit Singh died like the old Lion as he had lived. He preserved\nhis senses to the last, and was (which is unusual with the native princes)\nobeyed to the last by all his chiefs...\u201d <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">To this I will say \u2013AYE!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\nNelson Singh<br />\nFebruary 4, 2018 at 4:58 PM<br />\n<br />\ntalked to Veeresh sir now . he told me he did not block me. as you have told earlier zionist facebook is behind such a thing .<br />\n<br />\nsorry to trouble you sir . style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\nTHIS CANADIAN PM HAS AN AGENDA -- MODI IS SO FULL OF HIMSELF THAT HE DOES NOT KNOW WHAT THE HELL IS HAPPENING</div>\n<div style=\"font-size: 16px;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div
